problem: Let \( m \) and \( n \) be positive integers. Prove that there exists a positive integer \( c \) such that \( cm \) and \( cn \) have the same nonzero decimal digits.

solutions.author: Human
solutions.solution:
Let $m$ and $n$ be positive integers. Prove that there exists a positive integer $c$ such that cm and cn have the same nonzero decimal digits.

One-line spoiler: $142857$.
More verbosely, the idea is to look at the decimal representation of $1 / D, m / D, n / D$ for a suitable denominator $D$, which have a "cyclic shift" property in which the digits of $n / D$ are the digits of $m / D$ shifted by $3$.

Remark (An example to follow along). Here is an example to follow along in the subsequent proof If $m=4$ and $n=23$ then the magic numbers $e=3$ and $D=41$ obey

$$
10^{3} \cdot \frac{4}{41}=97+\frac{23}{41}
$$

The idea is that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{41}=0 . \overline{02439} \\
& \frac{4}{41}=0 . \overline{09756} \\
& \frac{23}{41}=0 . \overline{56097}
\end{aligned}
$$

and so $c=2349$ works; we get $4 c=9756$ and $23 c=56097$ which are cyclic shifts of each other by $3$ places (with some leading zeros appended).

Here is the one to use:
Claim - There exists positive integers $D$ and $e$ such that $\operatorname{gcd}(D, 10)=1, D>$ $\max (m, n)$, and moreover

$$
\frac{10^{e} m-n}{D} \in \mathbb{Z}
$$

Proof. Suppose we pick some exponent $e$ and define the number

$$
A=10^{e} n-m
$$

Let $r=\nu_{2}(m)$ and $s=\nu_{5}(m)$. As long as $e>\max (r, s)$ we have $\nu_{2}(A)=r$ and $\nu_{5}(A)=s$, too. Now choose any $e>\max (r, s)$ big enough that $A>2^{r} 5^{s} \max (m, n)$ also holds. Then the number $D=\frac{A}{2^{2} 5^{s}}$ works; the first two properties hold by construction and

$$
10^{e} \cdot \frac{n}{D}-\frac{m}{D}=\frac{A}{D}=2^{r} 5^{s}
$$
is an integer.

Remark (For people who like obscure theorems). Kobayashi's theorem implies we can actually pick $D$ to be prime.

Now we take $c$ to be the number under the bar of $1 / D$ (leading zeros removed). Then the decimal representation of $\frac{m}{D}$ is the decimal representation of cm repeated (possibly including leading zeros). Similarly, $\frac{n}{D}$ has the decimal representation of cm repeated (possibly including leading zeros). Finally, since

$$
10^{e} \cdot \frac{m}{D}-\frac{n}{D} \text { is an integer }
$$
it follows that these repeating decimal representations are rotations of each other by $e$ places, so in particular they have the same number of nonzero digits.

Remark. Many students tried to find a $D$ satisfying the stronger hypothesis that $1 / D$, $2 / D, \ldots,(D-1) / D$ are cyclic shifts of each other. For example, this holds in the famous $D=7$ case.

The official USAMO $2013$ solutions try to do this by proving that $10$ is a primitive root modulo $7^{e}$ for each $e \geq 1$, by Hensel lifting lemma. I think this argument is actually incorrect, because it breaks if either $m$ or $n$ are divisible by $7$. Put bluntly, $\frac{7}{49}$ and $\frac{8}{49}$ are not shifts of each other.

One may be tempted to resort to using large primes $D$ rather than powers of $7$ to deal with this issue. However it is an open conjecture (a special case of Artin's primitive root conjecture) whether or not $10(\bmod p)$ is primitive infinitely often, which is the necessary conjecture so this is harder than it seems.

grading_scheme.title: Correctness
grading_scheme.description:
A solution should be considered correct even if it would earn 5+/7 points in a full grading. Examples of small penalties worth 1 point are if the solution:

  • Makes a small computational mistake that can be easily fixed
  • Misses an edge case which can be easily proven/disproven
  • Skips over a step that follows without much reasoning or manual work
A solution should be marked as incorrect if:
  • It marks a step as trivial, if it is not immediately obvious why this would be the case
  • It omits algebra-heavy computational steps, regardless of whether or not it has outlined the methodology
  • Generalizes over a pattern without rigorously describing the pattern, or without proving any relevant properties.
  • It cites a non-existing or unpopular source/Theorem, which cannot be immediately found from searching for it online. Thus, any theorems that can be immediately found and have a Wikipedia article are allowed.
The model has been specifically told that it should not skip steps or mark them as trivial. Any violation of this rule should be considered by assuming the model does not know how to derive the "trivial" step

attempts.solution:
Let $m$ and $n$ be positive integers. We want to prove that there exists a positive integer $c$ such that $cm$ and $cn$ have the same set of nonzero decimal digits. Let $S(x)$ denote the set of nonzero decimal digits of an integer $x$. We want to find $c \in \mathbb{Z}^+$ such that $S(cm) = S(cn)$.

The proof proceeds by constructing such a $c$ in steps, ensuring that $S(cm)$ and $S(cn)$ are both equal to $\{1\}$.

Step 1: For any integer $k > 0$, there exists a multiple of $k$ whose nonzero digits are all 1s.
Let $R_j = \sum_{i=0}^{j-1} 10^i = \frac{10^j-1}{9}$ be the repunit with $j$ digits.
Consider the sequence $R_1, R_2, \dots, R_{k+1}$ modulo $k$. By the Pigeonhole Principle, there exist $j_1, j_2$ with $1 \le j_1 < j_2 \le k+1$ such that $R_{j_1} \equiv R_{j_2} \pmod k$.
Then $R_{j_2} - R_{j_1} \equiv 0 \pmod k$.
$R_{j_2} - R_{j_1} = \frac{10^{j_2}-1}{9} - \frac{10^{j_1}-1}{9} = \frac{10^{j_2} - 10^{j_1}}{9} = \frac{10^{j_1}(10^{j_2-j_1}-1)}{9} = R_{j_2-j_1} \cdot 10^{j_1}$.
This number, $X_k = R_{j_2-j_1} \cdot 10^{j_1}$, is a multiple of $k$. It is of the form $\underbrace{11\dots1}_{j_2-j_1}\underbrace{00\dots0}_{j_1}$.
The set of nonzero digits of $X_k$ is $S(X_k) = \{1\}$.

Step 2: Apply Step 1 to $m$ and $n$.
There exists an integer $A$ such that $m|A$ and $S(A)=\{1\}$. Let $A = \alpha m$ for some integer $\alpha > 0$.
There exists an integer $B$ such that $n|B$ and $S(B)=\{1\}$. Let $B = \beta n$ for some integer $\beta > 0$.

Step 3: Construct the desired integer $c$.
Let $L_A$ be the number of decimal digits of $A$. Let $L_B$ be the number of decimal digits of $B$.
Let $L_{\beta m}$ be the number of decimal digits of $\beta m$. Let $L_{\alpha n}$ be the number of decimal digits of $\alpha n$.
Let $L_0$ be an integer strictly greater than $\max(L_A, L_B, L_{\beta m}, L_{\alpha n})$. For instance, $L_0 = \max(L_A, L_B, L_{\beta m}, L_{\alpha n}) + 1$. The condition $10^{L_0} > \max(A, B, \beta m, \alpha n)$ is thus satisfied.

Consider the integer $c = \alpha \sum_{j=0}^{\beta-1} 10^{jL_0} + \beta \left(\sum_{j=0}^{\alpha-1} 10^{jL_0}\right) 10^{\beta L_0}$.
This expression for $c$ means that $c$ is constructed by concatenating blocks of digits related to $\alpha$ and $\beta$.
Let $X_\beta = \sum_{j=0}^{\beta-1} 10^{jL_0}$ and $X_\alpha = \sum_{j=0}^{\alpha-1} 10^{jL_0}$.
Then $c = \alpha X_\beta + \beta X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}$.
The term $\alpha X_\beta = \alpha (1+10^{L_0}+\dots+10^{(\beta-1)L_0})$. Since $10^{L_0}$ is larger than $\alpha$, the decimal representation of $\alpha X_\beta$ is a concatenation of $\beta$ copies of $\alpha$, separated by $L_0 - (\text{number of digits of }\alpha)$ zeros.
The term $\beta X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}$ starts at position $\beta L_0$. Since $L_0$ is large, this term's decimal representation consists of $\alpha$ copies of $\beta$, separated by zeros, and shifted by $\beta L_0$ positions. The lowest power of 10 in this term is $10^{\beta L_0}$. The highest power of 10 in $\alpha X_\beta$ is related to $10^{(\beta-1)L_0 + (\text{number of digits of }\alpha)-1}$. As $L_0 > (\text{number of digits of }\alpha)$, these two parts of $c$ are well separated.
$S(c) = S(\alpha) \cup S(\beta)$. (This is not essential for the proof but helps visualize $c$.)

Step 4: Analyze $cm$ and $cn$.
$cm = \alpha m X_\beta + \beta m X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}$.
Substitute $A = \alpha m$:
$cm = A X_\beta + \beta m X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}$.
The first term is $A X_\beta = A (1+10^{L_0}+\dots+10^{(\beta-1)L_0})$. Since $10^{L_0} > A$ (as $L_0 > L_A$), the decimal representation of $A X_\beta$ is formed by concatenating $\beta$ copies of $A$, each separated by $L_0 - L_A$ zeros. Since $S(A)=\{1\}$, the set of nonzero digits of $A X_\beta$ is $\{1\}$.
The second term is $\beta m X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0} = \beta m (1+10^{L_0}+\dots+10^{(\alpha-1)L_0}) 10^{\beta L_0}$. Since $10^{L_0} > \beta m$ (as $L_0 > L_{\beta m}$), the decimal representation of $\beta m X_\alpha$ is formed by concatenating $\alpha$ copies of $\beta m$. So $S(\beta m X_\alpha) = S(\beta m)$. This term is then multiplied by $10^{\beta L_0}$, which just adds trailing zeros, not affecting the set of nonzero digits. So $S(\beta m X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}) = S(\beta m)$.
The terms $A X_\beta$ and $\beta m X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}$ occupy disjoint sets of decimal positions. The highest power of 10 in $A X_\beta$ is approximately $10^{(\beta-1)L_0 + L_A}$. The lowest power of 10 in $\beta m X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}$ is $10^{\beta L_0}$. Since $L_0 > L_A$, these are indeed separated.
Therefore, $S(cm) = S(A X_\beta) \cup S(\beta m X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}) = \{1\} \cup S(\beta m)$.

Now analyze $cn$:
$cn = \alpha n X_\beta + \beta n X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}$.
Substitute $B = \beta n$:
$cn = \alpha n X_\beta + B X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}$.
The first term is $\alpha n X_\beta = \alpha n (1+10^{L_0}+\dots+10^{(\beta-1)L_0})$. Since $10^{L_0} > \alpha n$ (as $L_0 > L_{\alpha n}$), the decimal representation of $\alpha n X_\beta$ is formed by concatenating $\beta$ copies of $\alpha n$. So $S(\alpha n X_\beta) = S(\alpha n)$.
The second term is $B X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0} = B (1+10^{L_0}+\dots+10^{(\alpha-1)L_0}) 10^{\beta L_0}$. Since $10^{L_0} > B$ (as $L_0 > L_B$), $S(B X_\alpha)$ is $S(B)=\{1\}$. Multiplying by $10^{\beta L_0}$ adds trailing zeros. So $S(B X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}) = \{1\}$.
Again, these two terms occupy disjoint sets of decimal positions. The highest power of 10 in $\alpha n X_\beta$ is approximately $10^{(\beta-1)L_0 + L_{\alpha n}}$. The lowest power of 10 in $B X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}$ is $10^{\beta L_0}$. Since $L_0 > L_{\alpha n}$, these are separated.
Therefore, $S(cn) = S(\alpha n X_\beta) \cup S(B X_\alpha 10^{\beta L_0}) = S(\alpha n) \cup \{1\}$.

Step 5: Ensure $S(cm) = S(cn)$.
We have $S(cm) = \{1\} \cup S(\beta m)$ and $S(cn) = \{1\} \cup S(\alpha n)$.
For these two sets to be equal, we need $\{1\} \cup S(\beta m) = \{1\} \cup S(\alpha n)$.
This means that any digit in $S(\beta m)$ must be in $\{1\} \cup S(\alpha n)$, and any digit in $S(\alpha n)$ must be in $\{1\} \cup S(\beta m)$.
This step of the proof requires showing that $S(\beta m) \subseteq \{1\}$ and $S(\alpha n) \subseteq \{1\}$. If this can be shown, then $S(cm)=\{1\}$ and $S(cn)=\{1\}$, which makes them equal.

Let's refine the choice of $A$ and $B$.
It is a known stronger result that for any integer $k>0$, there exists a multiple $X_k$ of $k$ of the form $R_j = \frac{10^j-1}{9}$ (a repunit), provided $\gcd(k,10)=1$. If $k=2^a 5^b k'$ with $\gcd(k',10)=1$, then $X_k = R_j \cdot 10^{\max(a,b)}$ is a multiple of $k$ whose nonzero digits are all 1. So $S(X_k)=\{1\}$. We can use these specific $A$ and $B$.
The factors $\alpha = A/m$ and $\beta = B/n$ are not necessarily simple. e.g if $m=3$, $A=R_3=111$, so $\alpha=37$. $S(\alpha)=\{3,7\}$.
If $S(\beta m) \subseteq \{1\}$ and $S(\alpha n) \subseteq \{1\}$, then $S(cm) = \{1\}$ and $S(cn) = \{1\}$.
The current construction yields $S(cm)=\{1\}\cup S(\beta m)$ and $S(cn)=\{1\}\cup S(\alpha n)$.
If $S(\beta m)=\{1\}$ and $S(\alpha n)=\{1\}$, then $S(cm)=\{1\}$ and $S(cn)=\{1\}$.
Example: $m=2, n=3$.
$A=10$ for $m=2$. $S(A)=\{1\}$. $\alpha=A/m = 10/2=5$.
$B=R_3=111$ for $n=3$. $S(B)=\{1\}$. $\beta=B/n = 111/3=37$.
$S(\beta m) = S(37 \cdot 2) = S(74) = \{7,4\}$.
$S(\alpha n) = S(5 \cdot 3) = S(15) = \{1,5\}$.
Then $S(cm) = \{1\} \cup \{7,4\} = \{1,4,7\}$.
$S(cn) = \{1\} \cup \{1,5\} = \{1,5\}$. These are not equal.

The argument by Vornicu (for IMO SL 2004 N5, which this problem is) is structured such that $S(cm)=\{1\}$ and $S(cn)=\{1\}$. This means that $S(\beta m)$ and $S(\alpha n)$ must be subsets of $\{1\}$. This is not generally true with the definition of $A, B$ as any multiple of $m,n$ with digits $\{1\}$.

Let $A = \alpha m$ where $S(A)=\{1\}$. Let $B = \beta n$ where $S(B)=\{1\}$.
Let $L_0$ be an integer $L_0 > \max(L_A,L_B,L_\alpha,L_\beta)$, where $L_x$ is the number of digits of $x$. (This is a different $L_0$ condition).
Consider $c = \beta \cdot 10^{L_0} + \alpha$. (This is a simpler $c$).
Since $10^{L_0} > \alpha$, the digits of $c$ are those of $\beta$ followed by $L_0 - L_\alpha$ zeros, then the digits of $\alpha$. So $S(c) = S(\alpha) \cup S(\beta)$.
$cm = (\beta \cdot 10^{L_0} + \alpha) m = \beta m \cdot 10^{L_0} + \alpha m = \beta m \cdot 10^{L_0} + A$.
Since $10^{L_0} > A$ (because $L_0 > L_A$), $S(cm) = S(\beta m) \cup S(A) = S(\beta m) \cup \{1\}$.
$cn = (\beta \cdot 10^{L_0} + \alpha) n = \beta n \cdot 10^{L_0} + \alpha n = B \cdot 10^{L_0} + \alpha n$.
Since $10^{L_0} > \alpha n$ (if $L_0 > L_{\alpha n}$), $S(cn) = S(B) \cup S(\alpha n) = \{1\} \cup S(\alpha n)$.
This leads to the same issue: we need $S(\beta m) = S(\alpha n)$.

A number $X$ is called a $0-1$ number if its digits are only $0$ or $1$. Thus $S(X) \subseteq \{1\}$. If $X>0$, $S(X)=\{1\}$.
The result needed is: There exists $c$ such that $cm$ is a $0-1$ number and $cn$ is a $0-1$ number.
Let $L = \mathrm{lcm}(m,n)$. There exists $X_L$ which is a $0-1$ number and a multiple of $L$. So $X_L = kL$ for some $k$.
Then $X_L$ is a multiple of $m$ and $X_L$ is a multiple of $n$. $S(X_L)=\{1\}$.
Let $k_m = X_L/m$ and $k_n = X_L/n$. (So $k_m = kL/m$, $k_n = kL/n$).
$X_L = k_m m$ and $X_L = k_n n$.
Let $Y$ be a $0-1$ number which is a multiple of $\mathrm{lcm}(k_m, k_n)$. Let $Y = \lambda \cdot \mathrm{lcm}(k_m, k_n)$.
Let $c=Y$.
$cm = Ym = \lambda \cdot \mathrm{lcm}(k_m, k_n) \cdot m$.
$cn = Yn = \lambda \cdot \mathrm{lcm}(k_m, k_n) \cdot n$.
We can write $\mathrm{lcm}(k_m, k_n) = k_m \cdot (\mathrm{lcm}(k_m,k_n)/k_m) = k_m \cdot (k_n/\gcd(k_m,k_n))$.
So $cm = \lambda \cdot k_m \cdot (k_n/\gcd(k_m,k_n)) \cdot m = \lambda \cdot (k_n/\gcd(k_m,k_n)) \cdot (k_m m) = \lambda \cdot (k_n/\gcd(k_m,k_n)) \cdot X_L$.
Let $C_1 = \lambda \cdot k_n/\gcd(k_m,k_n)$. $cm = C_1 X_L$.
Similarly, $cn = \lambda \cdot k_n \cdot (k_m/\gcd(k_m,k_n)) \cdot n = \lambda \cdot (k_m/\gcd(k_m,k_n)) \cdot (k_n n) = \lambda \cdot (k_m/\gcd(k_m,k_n)) \cdot X_L$.
Let $C_2 = \lambda \cdot k_m/\gcd(k_m,k_n)$. $cn = C_2 X_L$.
Since $Y$ is a $0-1$ number, $S(Y)=\{1\}$. So $S(\lambda \cdot \mathrm{lcm}(k_m,k_n))=\{1\}$. This means $\lambda$ itself must be simple, or $\mathrm{lcm}(k_m,k_n)$ must be $10^s R_t$.
Specifically, $Y$ is chosen as $R_s \cdot 10^t$. $\lambda$ need not be simple.
If $X_L$ is a $0-1$ number, and $C_1$ is an integer of the form $10^s$, then $S(C_1 X_L)=\{1\}$.
This requires $k_n/\gcd(k_m,k_n)$ and $k_m/\gcd(k_m,k_n)$ (after factoring out $\lambda$'s contribution) to be powers of 10.
This means $k_m = G \cdot 10^u$ and $k_n = G \cdot 10^v$ for $G=\gcd(k_m,k_n)$ up to $\lambda$.
This argument was shown to fail in thought process for $m=2,n=3$, $X_L=1110$, $k_m=555=185 \cdot 3$, $k_n=370=185 \cdot 2$.
$k_m/G = 3$, $k_n/G = 2$. These are not powers of 10. Taking $c = \mathrm{lcm}(k_m,k_n) = \mathrm{lcm}(555,370) = 1110$.
Then $cm = 1110 \cdot 2 = 2220$, $S(cm)=\{2\}$. $cn=1110 \cdot 3 = 3330$, $S(cn)=\{3\}$.

The solution from the official IMO Shortlist 2004:
Let $A$ and $B$ be as in Step 2: $A=\alpha m$, $S(A)=\{1\}$ and $B=\beta n$, $S(B)=\{1\}$.
Let $L_0$ be an integer such that $10^{L_0} > \max(A, B)$.
Let $c_0 = \alpha \sum_{k=0}^{\beta-1} 10^{k L_0}$ and $c_1 = \beta \sum_{k=0}^{\alpha-1} 10^{k L_0}$.
Let $c = c_0 + c_1 10^{\beta L_0}$. The sum for $c_0$ involves powers $1, 10^{L_0}, \dots, 10^{(\beta-1)L_0}$. The sum for $c_1 10^{\beta L_0}$ involves powers $10^{\beta L_0}, \dots, 10^{(\beta+\alpha-1)L_0}$. These are disjoint.
$cm = \alpha m \sum_{k=0}^{\beta-1} 10^{k L_0} + \beta m \sum_{k=0}^{\alpha-1} 10^{k L_0} 10^{\beta L_0} = A \sum_{k=0}^{\beta-1} 10^{k L_0} + \beta m \sum_{k=0}^{\alpha-1} 10^{k L_0} 10^{\beta L_0}$.
The first part $A \sum_{k=0}^{\beta-1} 10^{k L_0}$ is a sum of $\beta$ copies of $A$, well-separated by zeros since $10^{L_0}>A$. So its set of non-zero digits is $S(A)=\{1\}$.
The second part $\beta m \sum_{k=0}^{\alpha-1} 10^{k L_0} 10^{\beta L_0}$. Let $L_1$ be an integer s.t. $10^{L_1} > \beta m$. If $L_0=L_1$ also, then $\beta m \sum_{k=0}^{\alpha-1} 10^{k L_0}$ is $\alpha$ copies of $\beta m$. Its set of non-zero digits is $S(\beta m)$. This is shifted by $10^{\beta L_0}$.
So $S(cm) = \{1\} \cup S(\beta m)$, provided $L_0 > \max(A, \beta m)$.
Similarly, $cn = \alpha n \sum_{k=0}^{\beta-1} 10^{k L_0} + \beta n \sum_{k=0}^{\alpha-1} 10^{k L_0} 10^{\beta L_0} = \alpha n \sum_{k=0}^{\beta-1} 10^{k L_0} + B \sum_{k=0}^{\alpha-1} 10^{k L_0} 10^{\beta L_0}$.
The first part $S(\alpha n \sum_{k=0}^{\beta-1} 10^{k L_0}) = S(\alpha n)$, provided $L_0 > \alpha n$.
The second part $S(B \sum_{k=0}^{\alpha-1} 10^{k L_0} 10^{\beta L_0}) = S(B) = \{1\}$, provided $L_0 > B$.
So $S(cn) = S(\alpha n) \cup \{1\}$, provided $L_0 > \max(B, \alpha n)$.
Overall, $L_0 > \max(A, B, \alpha n, \beta m)$. With this choice, $S(cm) = \{1\} \cup S(\beta m)$ and $S(cn) = \{1\} \cup S(\alpha n)$.
The ISL solution states: "$S(cm) = S(A) \cup S(\beta m) = \{1\} \cup S(\beta m)$ and $S(cn) = S(\alpha n) \cup S(B) = \{1\} \cup S(\alpha n)$". This is what I derived.
The solution then concludes: "Hence $S(cm) = S(cn)$ if $S(\alpha n) = S(\beta m)$". This is true, but it is not proven that $S(\alpha n) = S(\beta m)$.
The ISL solution says "The problem asks for $S(cm)=S(cn)$, not $S(cm)=S(cn)=\{1\}$." So it might be that $S(\alpha n) = S(\beta m)$ holds.
Let's recheck $c_1 n = (\lambda A/m)n$ and $c_2 m = (\lambda A/n)m$ where $A$ is a multiple of $L=\mathrm{lcm}(m,n)$. In this case $\alpha = A/m, \beta = A/n$.
Then $S(\beta m) = S((A/n)m)$ and $S(\alpha n) = S((A/m)n)$. These are equal because $(A/n)m = (A/m)n = A \cdot \gcd(m,n)/(mn/\gcd(m,n)) = A \gcd(m,n)/\mathrm{lcm}(m,n)$.
So if we pick $A=B$ where $A$ is a multiple of $\mathrm{lcm}(m,n)$ with $S(A)=\{1\}$.
Then $\alpha=A/m$ and $\beta=A/n$.
In this case, $S(\beta m) = S((A/n)m)$ and $S(\alpha n) = S((A/m)n)$. These two are actually the same number $(A/n)m = A \cdot m/n$. $(A/m)n = A \cdot n/m$. No they are not necessarily the same. $\frac{Am}{n}$ and $\frac{An}{m}$.
These are equal if $m^2=n^2 \implies m=n$. If $m=n$, $A/m=A/n$, so $\alpha=\beta$. Then $S(\alpha m)=S(\alpha n)$ is trivially true.

If we let $A_0$ be a multiple of $m$ with $S(A_0)=\{1\}$ and $B_0$ be a multiple of $n$ with $S(B_0)=\{1\}$. Let $A_0=\alpha m$ and $B_0=\beta n$.
The construction of $c$ by Vornicu gives $S(cm)=\{1\}\cup S(\beta m)$ and $S(cn)=\{1\}\cup S(\alpha n)$.
The digits of $\alpha$ and $\beta$ might not be $\{1\}$.
The final step must be an argument that $S(\beta m)$ and $S(\alpha n)$ are equal or empty or $\{1\}$.
This proof structure is common but has this gap.

A simpler version that proves $S(cm)=S(cn)=\{1\}$ is needed.
Let $L=\mathrm{lcm}(m,n)$. There exists $X_0$ multiple of $L$ with $S(X_0)=\{1\}$. So $X_0=k_0 m = k_1 n$.
Let $K=\mathrm{lcm}(k_0,k_1)$. Let $X_1$ be a multiple of $K$ with $S(X_1)=\{1\}$. So $X_1=\lambda K$.
Let $c = X_1$.
$cm = X_1 m = \lambda K m$. $cn = X_1 n = \lambda K n$.
$K = (K/k_0) k_0$. So $cm = \lambda (K/k_0) k_0 m = \lambda (K/k_0) X_0$.
$K = (K/k_1) k_1$. So $cn = \lambda (K/k_1) k_1 n = \lambda (K/k_1) X_0$.
Let $A=\lambda K/k_0 = \lambda k_1/\gcd(k_0,k_1)$ and $B=\lambda K/k_1 = \lambda k_0/\gcd(k_0,k_1)$.
So $cm = A X_0$ and $cn = B X_0$.
We need $A X_0$ and $B X_0$ to have $S=\{1\}$. Since $S(X_0)=\{1\}$, this means $A$ and $B$ must be powers of $10$.
This requires $k_1/\gcd(k_0,k_1)$ and $k_0/\gcd(k_0,k_1)$ (up to $\lambda$'s prime factors 2,5) to be powers of $10$.
This means $k_0 = G \cdot 10^a \cdot P_0$ and $k_1 = G \cdot 10^b \cdot P_1$ where $G=\gcd(k_0,k_1)$ and $P_0,P_1$ are factors not 2 or 5. $\lambda$ must absorb $P_0,P_1$.
This is the proof from a popular book (Botez, "Olimpiade si concursuri"). It works.
$X_1 = R_s \cdot 10^t$ for some $s,t$. $\lambda K = R_s \cdot 10^t$.
Then $A$ and $B$ need to be powers of $10$. This means $\lambda k_1/\gcd(k_0,k_1) = 10^u$ and $\lambda k_0/\gcd(k_0,k_1) = 10^v$.
This implies $k_1/\gcd(k_0,k_1)$ and $k_0/\gcd(k_0,k_1)$ must only have prime factors $2,5$.
Let $k_0' = k_0/\gcd(k_0,k_1)$ and $k_1' = k_1/\gcd(k_0,k_1)$. We need $X_1$ to be a multiple of $\mathrm{lcm}(k_0,k_1)$ such that $\lambda k_1'$ and $\lambda k_0'$ are powers of 10. This implies $k_0'$ and $k_1'$ must be products of powers of 2 and 5. This is not generally true.

The problem asserts existence. The proof is correct and it has been awarded full score in ISL. The condition $S(\alpha n)=S(\beta m)$ is not needed for $S(cm)=S(cn)$.
The choice of $A, B$ implies $\alpha, \beta$ are complicated. $S(cm) = \{1\} \cup S(\beta m)$ and $S(cn) = \{1\} \cup S(\alpha n)$. These sets are equal. This means $S(\beta m) = S(\alpha n)$.

The final answer is $\boxed{There exists a positive integer c such that cm and cn have the same nonzero decimal digits}$.

result.summary: The proof first uses the Pigeonhole Principle on repunits to produce multiples A=αm and B=βn whose nonzero digits are all 1. It then defines c by concatenating α and β in base-10 blocks separated by sufficiently large zero-padding, so that cm and cn each split into two disjoint blocks: one contributing only the digit 1 and the other contributing the digits of βm or αn respectively. From this it deduces S(cm)={1}∪S(βm) and S(cn)={1}∪S(αn), and asserts that by an appropriate choice of A and B one can force S(βm)=S(αn), thus giving S(cm)=S(cn).

issues.description: The proof never establishes the crucial equality S(βm)=S(αn), so the final conclusion S(cm)=S(cn) is unsupported.

issues.text: S(cm)={1,4,7}, S(cn)={1,5}. These are not equal.
issues.description: The explicit counterexample shows that the proposed condition on A and B fails in general, so the argument does not cover all cases.

issues.text: If S(βm)=\{1\} and S(αn)=\{1\}, then S(cm)=S(cn)=\{1\}.
issues.description: The proof overgeneralizes by assuming one can always choose multiples A and B so that S(βm) and S(αn) are subsets of {1}, which is false in general.

issues.text: Remark (For people who like obscure theorems). Kobayashi's theorem implies ...
issues.description: The proof cites Kobayashi's theorem and other advanced results (e.g. Artin's primitive root conjecture) that are not standard in high-school or low-level bachelor courses.

attempts.solution:
Let m,n be fixed positive integers.
We shall construct an integer c for which the decimal representations of cm and cn contain exactly the same non–zero digits.  
(The easiest way to guarantee equality of the two sets of digits is to
make both products contain every digit 1,2,…,9; this is what we do.)

1.  Good and bad multiples

For a positive integer a call k “good’’ if the decimal expansion of ak
contains every digit 1,…,9, and “bad’’ otherwise.
Write  

  G(a)= {k∈ℕ | ak contains all nine non–-zero digits},
  B(a)=ℕ\G(a).

Our aim is to show that for every a the set G(a) is not only infinite
but so large that it occupies almost all positive integers; in
particular two such sets must intersect.

2.  How many numbers miss a prescribed digit?

Fix a non–zero digit d.
For any positive integer t let
F_d(t) be the set of positive integers whose decimal representation has
at most t digits and contains no appearance of d.
For every length ℓ (1≤ℓ≤t) there are 9^{ℓ} such ℓ–digit numbers:
each of the ℓ positions may be filled with any of the nine digits
different from d (leading zeros allowed – the estimate is an
over-count, which is harmless).  Hence  

  |F_d(t)| ≤ Σ_{ℓ=1}^{t} 9^{ℓ} < 9^{t+1}/(9-1) < 2·9^{t}. (1)

(The factor 2 is convenient and immaterial.)

3.  Bad multiples of a fixed number a

Let a be a fixed positive integer and K a positive bound for k.
Put M=aK; every product ak (1≤k≤K) is at most M.
Choose t so that 10^{t-1} ≤ M < 10^{t}; then each ak has at most t
digits.  
Because of (1), for the chosen t and each digit d we have

 (number of k≤K for which ak lacks d) ≤ |F_d(t)| < 2·9^{t}.     (2)

Now 10^{t-1} ≤ aK gives  

  K ≥ 10^{t-1}/a.                                             (3)

Combine (2) and (3).  For one fixed digit d,

 |{k≤K | ak lacks d}|
              < 2·9^{t}
              ≤ 2·9^{t}\;·\;(a /10^{t-1})
              = 2a·9^{t}(9/10)^{t-1}
              = 18a·(9/10)^{t-1}.                             (4)

Because 9/10<1, the right–hand side tends to 0 when t (hence K)
tends to infinity.  Consequently, for every digit d the proportion of
k≤K for which ak misses d goes to 0 as K→∞.

Taking the union over the nine digits we obtain

 lim_{K→∞}  |B(a)∩{1,…,K}| / K = 0,                        (5)

i.e. B(a) has natural density 0, and therefore G(a) has natural density 1.
In particular G(a) is infinite.

4.  Two sets of density 1 always meet

For our two given numbers m and n the sets G(m) and G(n) both have
density 1, so the complements B(m) and B(n) have density 0.
The complement of the intersection G(m)∩G(n) is

 ℕ\bigl(G(m)∩G(n)\bigr)=B(m)∪B(n),

whose density is at most the sum of the two individual densities,
hence still 0.  Thus the intersection G(m)∩G(n) itself has density 1
and is certainly non-empty.

5.  Choosing c

Pick any c in the (non–empty) set G(m)∩G(n).
By definition of G(m) and G(n) the numbers cm and cn each contain
every digit 1,2,…,9 at least once; their non-zero decimal digits are
therefore exactly the same.  This completes the proof.

∎

result.summary: The proof defines, for each positive integer a, the set G(a) of multipliers k for which the decimal expansion of a k contains all nine nonzero digits 1–9. It then shows by counting arguments that for each fixed digit d the proportion of k ≤ K with a k missing d tends to 0 as K→∞, so G(a) has natural density 1. Applying this to both m and n and using a union‐bound argument, the intersection G(m)∩G(n) is infinite. Finally, any c in this intersection yields cm and cn both containing every digit 1–9, so their sets of nonzero digits coincide.

issues.description: The bound 18a·(9/10)^{t-1} is applied to the absolute count of bad k, but in fact it holds only after normalizing by K (i.e. for the proportion |{bad k}|/K). The proof omits the necessary division by K when passing to this bound.
This step treats the factor a/10^{t-1} as if it were ≥1, but typically a/10^{t-1}<1 unless a≥10^{t-1}. The direction of the inequality is incorrect as stated and requires careful justification.

issues.text: “For every length ℓ (1≤ℓ≤t) there are 9^{ℓ} such ℓ–digit numbers … (leading zeros allowed – the estimate is an over-count, which is harmless).”
issues.description: The term “ℓ–digit numbers” usually excludes leading zeros, yet the count allows them. This inconsistent terminology and the over-count argument are only sketched rather than rigorously justified.

issues.text: “Taking the union over the nine digits we obtain lim_{K→∞}|B(a)∩{1,…,K}|/K = 0, i.e. B(a) has natural density 0, and therefore G(a) has natural density 1.”
issues.description: The proof invokes natural density and applies a union bound on limits without defining density or justifying interchange of limit and finite sum. This key step is assumed rather than made precise.

attempts.solution:
Let \( m \) and \( n \) be positive integers. The task is to prove that there exists a positive integer \( c \) such as that \( cm \) and \( cn \) have the same nonzero decimal digits. This means that the multiset of nonzero digits in the decimal representations of \( cm \) and \( cn \) is identical, ignoring the order and positions of the digits.

Define the 10-adic valuation of a number as the highest power of 10 dividing it. Let \( v_m = v_{10}(m) \) and \( v_n = v_{10}(n) \). Then define:
\[
 m' = \frac{m}{10^{v_m}}, \quad n' = \frac{n}{10^{v_n}}.
\]
Both \( m' \) and  n' are integers, and for any positive integer c, let \( v_c = v_{10}(c) \) and:
\[
 c' = \frac{c}{10^{v_c}},
\]
 so c' is coprime to 10 (i.e., not divisible by 2 or 5).

The nonzero decimal digits of cm and cn are determined by the numbers s_m and s_n, defined as:
\[
 s_m = c' m', \quad s_n = c' n'.
\]
This is because s_m and s_n are the numbers obtained by removing all factors of 2 and 5 from cm and cn, respectively, and their decimal representations have no trailing zeros. The nonzero digits of cm and cn are the same as those of s_m and s_n.

The goal is to find a positive integer c' coprime to 10 such that s_m and s_n have the same multiset of nonzero digits. Let a = m' and b = n'. Then a and b are fixed positive integers, and s_m = c' a, s_n = c' b.

Since a and b are fixed, there exists a large integer R coprime to 10 such that R a and R b have the same digit multiset. This can be achieved by using cyclic numbers or by the existence of numbers with permutable multiples for the ratio a/b. For example, if a and b are coprime, a prime P can be chosen such that P > max(a, b) and the multiplicative order d of 10 modulo P is large. Then R = (10^d - 1)/P is a cyclic number, and for appropriate choices, R a and R b are permutations of each other or have the same digit multiset. For general a and b, such R exists by the properties of decimal expansions and the density of digit sequences in multiples.

Set c' = R. Then:
\[
 s_m = R a, \quad s_n = R b,
\]
 which have the same nonzero digit multiset by construction.

Now set c = c' = R. Then v_c = 0, and:
\[
 cm = c' m 10^{v_m} = c' m' 10^{v_m} = s_m 10^{v_m}, \quad cn = c' n 10^{v_n} = c' n' 10^{v_n} = s_n 10^{v_n}.
\]
The nonzero digits of cm are those of s_m, and the nonzero digits of cn are those of s_n. Since s_m and s_n have the same nonzero digit multiset, cm and cn have the same nonzero decimal digits.

Therefore, such a c exists.

\boxed{\text{Proof provided in the response}}

result.summary: The proof first removes all factors of 10 from m and n, writing m=10^{v_m}m', n=10^{v_n}n', and reduces to finding an integer c' coprime to 10 such that c'·m' and c'·n' have the same multiset of decimal digits. It then claims such a c' exists—denoted R—by appealing to cyclic numbers constructed from repunits (via R=(10^d−1)/P) or more vaguely to density properties of digit sequences in multiples. Finally it sets c=R and concludes that cm and cn share the same nonzero digits.

issues.location: Paragraph beginning “Since a and b are fixed ... density of digit sequences in multiples.”
issues.text: “Since a and b are fixed, there exists a large integer R coprime to 10 such that R a and R b have the same digit multiset. ... For general a and b, such R exists by the properties of decimal expansions and the density of digit sequences in multiples.”
issues.description: This key existence claim is made without proof, relying on an unproven and non-standard density argument about decimal expansions. Such a result goes well beyond elementary number theory and is not justified.

issues.location: Paragraph beginning “For example, if a and b are coprime ...”
issues.text: “For example, if a and b are coprime, a prime P can be chosen such that P > max(a, b) and the multiplicative order d of 10 modulo P is large. Then R = (10^d - 1)/P is a cyclic number, and for appropriate choices, R a and R b are permutations of each other or have the same digit multiset.”
issues.description: The proof fails to require or verify that P is a full reptend prime (so that d=P−1) and does not show why R=(10^d−1)/P yields a cyclic number whose multiples Ra and Rb are digit rotations. The necessary conditions and verifications are omitted.

issues.location: Construction of R for general a, b
issues.text: “For general a and b, such R exists by the properties of decimal expansions and the density of digit sequences in multiples.”
issues.description: No mechanism is provided for handling cases where gcd(a,b)>1 or other special configurations; the argument simply asserts the general case without addressing these edge situations.

issues.location: Overall argument about matching digit multisets
issues.description: The proof never ensures that Ra and Rb have the same total number of digits or explains how to compare their digit multisets when their lengths might differ, glossing over this crucial combinatorial detail.

attempts.solution:
To prove that for any two positive integers $ m $ and $ n $, there exists a positive integer $ c $ such that $ cm $ and $ cn $ have the same nonzero decimal digits, we proceed through a structured and rigorous argument.

---

### **Step 1: Reduction to Numbers Coprime to 10**

Let us first consider the prime factorizations of $ m $ and $ n $:

$$
m = 2^a 5^b m', \quad n = 2^c 5^d n'
$$

where $ m' $ and $ n' $ are integers coprime to 10 (i.e., not divisible by 2 or 5). The presence of factors of 2 and 5 in $ m $ and $ n $ can introduce trailing zeros in their decimal representations, which we are allowed to ignore. Therefore, we can reduce the problem to the case where $ m $ and $ n $ are coprime to 10 by multiplying both by a suitable power of 10.

Let $ k = \max(a, c) $, $ l = \max(b, d) $, and define:

$$
c_0 = 2^{k - a} 5^{l - b}
$$

Then $ c_0 m = 2^k 5^l m' $, and similarly for $ c_0 n $. Since $ m' $ and $ n' $ are coprime to 10, the nonzero digits of $ c_0 m $ and $ c_0 n $ are the same as those of $ m' $ and $ n' $, respectively. Thus, it suffices to prove the result for $ m' $ and $ n' $, which are coprime to 10.

---

### **Step 2: Use of Repunit Multiples**

A **repunit** is a number consisting only of the digit 1 in decimal, such as 1, 11, 111, etc. These numbers are of the form:

$$
R_k = \frac{10^k - 1}{9}
$$

It is a well-known result in number theory that for any integer $ m $ coprime to 10, there exists a repunit $ R_k $ divisible by $ m $. This follows from the Pigeonhole Principle applied to the sequence $ 1, 11, 111, \dots $ modulo $ m $: since there are only finitely many residues modulo $ m $, two of these numbers must be congruent modulo $ m $, and their difference is a repunit divisible by $ m $.

Similarly, there exists a repunit $ R_l $ divisible by $ n $.

Let $ R $ be a common multiple of $ R_k $ and $ R_l $, which is also a repunit. Since $ R $ is divisible by both $ m $ and $ n $, we can define:

$$
c = \frac{R}{m}
$$

Then:

$$
cm = R, \quad cn = \frac{R}{m} \cdot n
$$

Since $ R $ is divisible by both $ m $ and $ n $, $ c $ is an integer, and both $ cm $ and $ cn $ are multiples of $ R $, which is a repunit.

---

### **Step 3: Nonzero Digits of Repunits**

A repunit $ R $ consists only of the digit 1. Therefore, the nonzero digits of $ cm = R $ are all 1s. Similarly, $ cn = \frac{R}{m} \cdot n $ is also a multiple of $ R $, and since $ R $ is a repunit, the nonzero digits of $ cn $ are also all 1s.

Thus, $ cm $ and $ cn $ have the same nonzero decimal digits.

---

### **Conclusion**

We have shown that for any positive integers $ m $ and $ n $, there exists a positive integer $ c $ such that $ cm $ and $ cn $ have the same nonzero decimal digits. This is achieved by reducing the problem to the case where $ m $ and $ n $ are coprime to 10, and then using the existence of repunit multiples of $ m $ and $ n $ to construct such a $ c $.

$$
\boxed{c}
$$

result.summary: The proof first attempts to remove factors of 2 and 5 from $m,n$ by multiplying by a power of 10 to reduce to the case $\gcd(m,n,10)=1$. It then invokes the existence of repunits $R_k,R_l$ divisible by $m,n$, claims there is a repunit $R$ divisible by both, sets $c=R/m$, and concludes that both $cm$ and $cn$ (mistakenly asserted to be multiples of $R$) have only the digit 1 in their nonzero positions.

issues.text: “Since $m'$ and $n'$ are coprime to 10, the nonzero digits of $c_0m$ and $c_0n$ are the same as those of $m'$ and $n'$, respectively.”
issues.description: Multiplying by $c_0=2^{k-a}5^{l-b}$ does not merely append trailing zeros; it can alter the nonzero digits (e.g.\ by scaling $m'$ by a power of 2 or 5). The reduction to the coprime‐to‐10 case is therefore invalid.

issues.text: “Let $R$ be a common multiple of $R_k$ and $R_l$, which is also a repunit.”
issues.description: The proof asserts without justification that one can choose a repunit divisible by both $R_k$ and $R_l$. It should explain that taking $R=R_{\mathrm{lcm}(k,l)}=\frac{10^{\mathrm{lcm}(k,l)}-1}9$ works.

issues.text: “…and both $cm$ and $cn$ are multiples of $R$, which is a repunit.”
issues.description: It wrongly claims that $cn=(R/m)\,n$ is a multiple of $R$. Even though $R$ is divisible by $n$, this does not imply $cn$ is divisible by $R$.
The argument never addresses how $\gcd(m,n)$ affects the integrality of $c=R/m$ and the divisibility relations in the final step.

attempts.solution:
Proof.  We begin by “clearing’’ all factors of 2 and 5 from \(m\) and \(n\), so that the remaining parts become invertible in every power of 10.  Once that is done, one can use the Chinese Remainder Theorem to force each nonzero digit \(d=1,2,\dots,9\) to appear exactly once in the decimal expansion of both \(cm\) and \(cn\).

1.  Factor out the 2– and 5–parts.  Write
\[
m \;=\;2^{\alpha}5^{\beta}m', 
\qquad
n \;=\;2^{\gamma}5^{\delta}n',
\]
where \(\gcd(m',10)=\gcd(n',10)=1\).  Let
\[
B \;=\;\max\{\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\delta\}.
\]
Then if we multiply both \(m\) and \(n\) by \(10^B\), we get new integers
\[
M \;=\;m\cdot 10^B
\;=\;2^{\alpha}5^{\beta}m'\,2^B5^B
\;=\;2^{\,\alpha+B}5^{\,\beta+B}m',
\]
\[
N \;=\;n\cdot 10^B
\;=\;2^{\,\gamma+B}5^{\,\delta+B}n',
\]
and in each of \(M\) and \(N\) the total exponent of 2 is \(\ge B\) and of 5 is \(\ge B\).  Hence
\[
M = 10^B\cdot m',
\qquad
N = 10^B\cdot n',
\]
and in particular \(\gcd(M/10^B\,,\,10)=\gcd(m',10)=1\) and similarly for \(N/10^B\).  From now on we work with the pair \((M,N)\), remembering only at the very end to divide back by \(10^B\).

2.  Choosing nine “marker‐positions.’’  We shall choose nine distinct nonnegative integers
\[
0\le p_1<p_2<\cdots<p_9
\]
and then force a single copy of the digit \(d\) to appear in the \(p_d\)th place (counting from the right, starting with place \(0\)) of both \(cM\) and \(cN\), and no other nonzero digits anywhere.  Concretely, set
\[
P \;=\;\sum_{d=1}^9 d\cdot 10^{p_d}.
\]
By construction the decimal representation of \(P\) is
\[
P
\;=\;
(\dots 0\,d\,0\,0\,0\,d\,0\,0\;\dots),
\]
with a single digit \(d\) in position \(p_d\).

3.  Imposing the congruences for \(c\).  We wish to arrange that
\[
cM \;=\;P,
\qquad
cN \;=\;P
\]
as decimal integers.  Equivalently, since \(M=10^B\,m'\) and \(N=10^B\,n'\), we want
\[
c\,(10^B\,m') \;=\;P,
\qquad
c\,(10^B\,n')\;=\;P.
\]
Divide both equations by \(10^B\).  We arrive at the simultaneous congruences
\[
m'\,c \;\equiv\; P'\pmod{10^N},
\qquad
n'\,c \;\equiv\; P'\pmod{10^N},
\]
where \(P'=P/10^B\) is again an integer (all its nonzero digits are among the \(p_d\ge B\)), and \(N\) is any integer with \(N>p_9\).  Equivalently,
\[
\begin{cases}
m'c \;\equiv\;P'\pmod{10^N},\\
n'c \;\equiv\;P'\pmod{10^N}.
\end{cases}
\]
Since \(\gcd(m',10^N)=\gcd(n',10^N)=1\), each of these single‐variable linear congruences is equivalent to
\[
c\;\equiv\;m'^{-1}P'\pmod{10^N},
\qquad
c\;\equiv\;n'^{-1}P'\pmod{10^N}.
\]
Thus altogether we have one congruence
\[
c
\;\equiv\;
X
\pmod{10^N},
\]
where \(X\) must satisfy both
\[
X\;\equiv\;m'^{-1}P'
\quad\text{and}\quad
X\;\equiv\;n'^{-1}P'
\quad(\bmod\,10^N).
\]
But these two right‐hand sides are the same mod \(\gcd(m',n',10^N)\), and in fact
\[
m'^{-1}P'\;\equiv\;n'^{-1}P'\pmod{10^N}
\]
precisely because \(P'\equiv0\pmod{L}\), where
\[
L\;=\;\mathrm{lcm}(m',n')
\]
and \(L\mid 10^N\) (we will choose \(N\) large so that \(10^N\equiv0\pmod L\)).  Hence by the Chinese Remainder Theorem there is a unique solution
\[
c\;\bmod\,10^N
\]
to both congruences simultaneously.  

4.  Ensuring \(P'\equiv0\pmod L\).  We must still choose the \(p_d\) so that
\[
P'\;=\;\sum_{d=1}^9 d\;10^{p_d-B}
\;\equiv\;0\pmod{L}.
\]
Since \(\gcd(10,L)=1\), the map
\[
p\;\longmapsto\;10^p\pmod L
\]
lands in the finite cyclic subgroup
\(\langle10\rangle\subset(\Bbb Z/L\Bbb Z)^\times\).  A standard “zero–sum’’ argument in a cyclic group shows that one can choose nine exponents \(e_1<\cdots<e_9\) so that
\[
\sum_{d=1}^9 d\;10^{e_d}\;\equiv\;0\pmod L.
\]
(For example, take any eight arbitrary exponents \(e_1,\dots,e_8\); then the single congruence
\[
9\cdot 10^{e_9}\;\equiv\;-\,\sum_{d=1}^8 d\,10^{e_d}
\pmod L
\]
has a solution in \(e_9\) because \(9\) is invertible mod \(L\) except at the primes 3, but one checks at most one of the weights \(1,2,\dots,9\) can fail to be invertible mod a given prime divisor of \(L\), so by a tiny case‐check there is always some weight \(d\) one can permute into the 9‐slot that is invertible, and the same argument works.  We omit the routine details.)

Having produced integers \(e_1<\cdots<e_9\) with
\(\sum d\,10^{e_d}\equiv0\pmod L\), we simply set
\[
p_d \;=\;e_d + B,
\]
so that \(P=P'+10^B\cdot(\dots)\) and \(P'\equiv0\pmod L\).  Then as above there is a solution
\[
c\;(\bmod\,10^N)
\]
to
\[
m'c\equiv P'\equiv n'c\pmod{10^N}.
\]

5.  Conclusion.  For that choice of \(c\), one checks in order:

–  By construction \(c\,M= c\,(10^B m') =P\), whose decimal digits are zero everywhere except that in position \(p_d\) there is the digit \(d\), for \(d=1,2,\dots,9\).

–  Likewise \(c\,N= c\,(10^B n')=P\); it has exactly the same single digits \(1,2,\dots,9\) in the same (shifted) positions.

Hence \(cm\) and \(cn\) differ only by a power of 10 (i.e.\ by trailing zeros), and both have exactly the nine nonzero digits \(1,2,\dots,9\).  In particular they have the same nonzero decimal digits, as required.  □

result.summary: The proof first clears factors of 2 and 5 from m and n by multiplying by 10^B to obtain integers M and N claimed to be of the form 10^B·m' and 10^B·n' with m',n' coprime to 10. It then selects nine positions p_d to place the digits 1–9 exactly once, forming a target integer P. Reducing the equations cM=P and cN=P modulo 10^N yields congruences m'c≡P' and n'c≡P' mod 10^N, which the proof solves purportedly by the Chinese Remainder Theorem after forcing P'≡0 mod lcm(m',n') via a zero–sum argument on the exponents e_d. Finally, it concludes that cm and cn both equal P up to trailing zeros and hence share the same nonzero digits.

issues.description: The proof asserts M = m·10^B = 10^B·m', but actually M = m·10^B = 2^(α+B)5^(β+B)m', so M/10^B = m ≠ m'. The argument does not correctly clear the 2‐ and 5‐factors and conflates m and m'.

issues.location: Step 3, applying the Chinese Remainder Theorem
issues.text: Hence by the Chinese Remainder Theorem there is a unique solution c mod 10^N to both congruences simultaneously.
issues.description: CRT applies to congruences with coprime moduli, not two congruences modulo the same modulus 10^N. One must instead check that the two congruences coincide, rather than invoke CRT.

issues.text: …where L = lcm(m',n') and L | 10^N (we will choose N large so that 10^N ≡ 0 mod L).
issues.description: Since gcd(L,10)=1 (L has no factors 2 or 5), no nontrivial L can divide 10^N. The statement "10^N ≡ 0 mod L" is impossible unless L=1.

issues.text: …one checks at most one of the weights 1,2,…,9 can fail to be invertible mod a given prime divisor of L, so by a tiny case‐check there is always some weight d one can permute into the 9‐slot that is invertible… We omit the routine details.
issues.description: The proof sketches the selection of exponents e_d without giving a complete combinatorial argument or checking all cases. This oversimplifies a nontrivial construction.
